title: Bounding Large-Scale Bell Inequalities
abstract:
Bell inequalities are an important tool for studying non-locality, however
quickly become computationally intractable as the system size grows. We
consider a novel method for finding an upper bound for the quantum violation of
such inequalities by combining the NPA hierarchy, the method of alternating
projections, and the memory-efficient optimisation algorithm L-BFGS. Whilst our
method may not give the tightest upper bound possible, it often does so several
orders of magnitude faster than state-of-the-art solvers, with minimal memory
usage, thus allowing solutions to problems that would otherwise be intractable.
We benchmark using the well-studied I3322 inequality as well as a more general
large-scale randomized inequality RXX22. For randomized inequalities with 130
inputs either side (a first-level moment matrix of size 261x261), our method is
~100x faster than both MOSEK and SCS whilst giving a bound only ~2% above the
optimum.
